KCD to perform 'The Miracle Worker'

kclark2@courier-journal.com 3:46 p.m. EDT October 24, 2014
Buy Photo

Kentucky Country Day's Allie Hail as Helen Keller, left, and Annie Scharf, as Annie Sullivan rehearse the Miracle Worker. Oct. 23, 2014(Photo: Scott Utterback/The C-J)Buy Photo

CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

It was after school on a Thursday, and Allie Hail, 16, was throwing a tantrum. She stomped her feet on the floor and pounded her fists against the kitchen table until the silverware bounced across the table and ricocheted onto the floor.

Maggie Brown, 16, who had been sitting beside Allie and watching everything unfold, wrestled her to the ground.

"And lights," Kate Scinta, who teaches theater at Kentucky Country Day School's upper school, instructed from the front row of the auditorium. "Not bad."

The scene was from the play "The Miracle Worker," based on the true story of young Helen Keller, played by Allie, and her teacher Annie Sullivan, played by Maggie. It's one of the young actors' favorite scenes in the entire play, one that took hours to come together.

Kentucky Country Day's Allie Hail as Helen Keller, center, rehearses a scene were she figures out how to sign "mother" and "father." Syles Cole as Captain Keller, right, Maggie Brown as Annie Sullivan, left, and Skylar Brown as Kate Keller are also in this scene of the Miracle Worker. Oct. 23, 2014  (Photo: Scott Utterback/The C-J)

    The play tells the story of 20-year-old Annie Sullivan, who comes to Tuscumbia, Alabama in 1888 to teach Helen Keller who is blind, deaf and mute to communicate despite her physical limitations.

    The classic drama opens at Kentucky Country Day on Oct. 31 and runs through Nov. 2. A community dress rehearsal with American Sign Language interpretation will take place 10 a.m. Oct. 30.

    The role of Helen Keller proved challenging for Allie, who said she doesn't personally know anyone who is blind or deaf.

    "It's really hard to portray someone who's blind and deaf because it's a completely different world to them," she said.

    To prepare for the role, she studied actresses who had portrayed young Helen Keller on screen. She also took some cues from Kentucky School for the Blind students, who met with KCD's 14-member cast in preparation for the show.

    "We're really trying to emphasize diversity at our school, and we talk about ethnic diversity and we talk about gender equality, but we really don't do a whole lot with blindness and deafness," said Scinta, who is directing the show. "We don't have any blind or deaf students at our school."

    The talk introduced KCD students to individuals in the blind and deaf communities, she said.

    "I think our kids were really shocked because they realized that these students who were blind were individuals just as they are they're high school kids," said Scinta.

    Eleventh grade student Annie Scharf, who shares the role of Annie Sullivan with Maggie, said she learned a lot from the Kentucky School for the Blind visitors.

    "This is going to sound cheesy but they were real people," she said. "They were funny, and they were awesome people."

    Reporter Kirsten Clark can be reached at (502) 582-4144 or on Twitter @kirstenlmclark.

    'The Miracle Worker'

    What: a classic drama about the story of Helen Keller and Annie Sullivan, as performed by Kentucky Country Day upper school students

    When: 7:30 p.m. on Oct. 31 and Nov. 1, 3 p.m. on Nov. 2. There will also be a community dress rehearsal for the sight and hearing impaired at 10 a.m. Oct. 30. American Sign Language interpretation will be provided.

    Where: Kentucky Country Day Theater, 4100 Springdale Rd.

    For more information, go to kcdtheater.org.
